column4: I forwarded port A to a computer in my local network. I can access a computer in my local network using its local ip, but not using the 'outgoing' internet IP. Any suggestions?
a lot of times a router won't route out and right back in to the network
i run into it all the time on many different forms of routers
is there a way to fix this?
it's router behavior, it won't send the packets out on the same interface it recieved them on
it would send it on to the next router, but it is the destination
it's just how routing works.
so It receives tham on ip A which is the internet ip and must send them to ip B
forwards don't take effect from the internal interfaces.
what do you mean with that?

now, i have problems if i try to go to my web site from inside, because it goes to the firewall and doesn't forward, so i just use a hosts entry to make it go to the right internal ip rather than the one that DNS provides
so is there another way to check my networked application?
you could connect to an outside computer and try to connect in
yeah I thought the same.. and that does indeed work.. BUT
as in to localhost?
if it's connecting to another machine on the internal network, tell it to connect to the internal ip.
no. I've uploaded my flash movie to A, than I load the swf using my browser. The swf makes a connection to my internal xml server.
and therfore I probably can't connect to it
as i said, try connecting to an outside machine w/ remote desktop or vnc, and connect back in
yes thanx
other than that, i don't think your going to accomplish what you want...
thanx!
